The remarkably regulated expression of Xlr in the lymphoid cell lineage and of its homologue Xmr in the germ cell lineage suggests that they might play an important role in chromatin metabolism at critical stages of differentiation during which the genome undergoes irreversible rearrangements.

column1: Smoking is a risk factor for complications during and after surgery
column2: but most smokers are unable to quit before elective surgery. We tested the efficacy of bupropion in improving smoking cessation rates in this setting by enrolling 47 patients from the elective surgery waiting list in a double-blind randomised controlled trial. Patients receiving bupropion had a lower daily cigarette consumption at the time of hospital admission
column3: median (IQR) cigarettes per day: 6 (2-7) vs. 15 (9-20)
column4: p = 0.046. They also had a reduction in end-expired carbon monoxide (p = 0.004)
column5: a known contaminant of cigarette smoke
column6: and increased arterial oxygen saturation on pulse oximetry (p = 0.011). They were more likely to have stopped smoking at the 3-week visit (p = 0.036)
column7: but not at the 6-week visit (p = 0.25) or at the time of hospital admission for surgery (p > 0.99). This study found that smokers waiting for elective surgery are more likely to reduce or stop smoking when treated with bupropion.

column1: OBJECTIVE: To determine the utility of ultrasonography in guiding modification of disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drug (DMARD) and steroid therapy for inflammatory arthritis (IA) in routine clinical practice.METHODS: In this retrospective study
column2: we analyzed DMARD and steroid use in IA patients referred to a rheumatologist-led ultrasound clinic. Power Doppler (PD) vascularity and greyscale (GS) synovial hypertrophy joint findings were categorized as positive/negative for each patient. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was used as a measure of disease activity.RESULTS: We assessed single visit data for 46 adult IA patients: 67.4% (n = 31) rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
column3: 15.2% (n = 7) psoriatic arthritis
column4: 10.9% (n = 5) spondyloarthritis
column5: and 6.5% (n = 3) undifferentiated IA. The mean ESR was 28.8 mm/h. Thirty-seven patients with both GS and PD ultrasound results were subsequently analyzed. All patients (n = 10) escalated and/or initiated on DMARD and 9/10 patients escalated or initiated on steroids were PD and GS positive. Six of seven patients with dose reduction and/or cessation of DMARDs and five of seven patients with dose reduction or cessation of steroids were PD negative. Of six patients who were GS positive and PD negative
column6: three had dose reduction and/or cessation of DMARDs
column7: while four had dose reduction of steroids; none of the six patients had DMARD/steroid escalation.CONCLUSION: By clarifying joint inflammation in an IA cohort with overall low ESR
column8: ultrasonography of physician-selected joints can improve clinical assessment
column9: resulting in treatment modification. Positive PD findings were particularly influential
column10: while the clinical significance of GS positivity alone requires further investigation.

column1: G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell surface receptors that detect a wide range of extracellular messengers and convey this information to the inside of cells. Extracellular calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) and ovarian cancer gene receptor 1 (OGR1) are two GPCRs that sense extracellular Ca(2+) and H(+)
column2: respectively. These two ions are key components of the interstitial fluid
column3: and their concentrations change in an activity-dependent manner. Importantly
column4: the interstitial fluid forms part of the microenvironment that influences cell function in health and disease; however
column5: the exact mechanisms through which changes in the microenvironment influence cell function remain largely unknown. We show that CaSR and OGR1 reciprocally inhibit signaling through each other in central neurons
column6: and that this is lost in their transformed counterparts. Furthermore
column7: strong intracellular acidification impairs CaSR function
column8: but potentiates OGR1 function. Thus
column9: CaSR and OGR1 activities can be regulated in a seesaw manner
column10: whereby conditions promoting signaling through one receptor simultaneously inhibit signaling through the other receptor
column11: potentiating the difference in their relative signaling activity. Our results provide insight into how small but consistent changes in the ionic microenvironment of cells can significantly alter the balance between two signaling pathways
column12: which may contribute to disease progression.

column1: Here we present the development and implementation of a genome-wide reverse genetic screen in the budding yeast
column2: Saccharomyces cerevisiae
column3: that couples high-throughput strain growth
column4: robotic RNA isolation and cDNA synthesis
column5: and quantitative PCR to allow for a robust determination of the level of nearly any cellular RNA in the background of ~5
column6: 500 different mutants. As an initial test of this approach
column7: we sought to identify the full complement of factors that impact pre-mRNA splicing. Increasing lines of evidence suggest a relationship between pre-mRNA splicing and other cellular pathways including chromatin remodeling
column8: transcription
column9: and 3' end processing
column10: yet in many cases the specific proteins responsible for functionally connecting these pathways remain unclear. Moreover
column11: it is unclear whether all pathways that are coupled to splicing have been identified. As expected
column12: our approach sensitively detects pre-mRNA accumulation in the vast majority of strains containing mutations in known splicing factors. Remarkably
column13: however
column14: several additional candidates were found to cause increases in pre-mRNA levels similar to that seen for canonical splicing mutants
column15: none of which had previously been implicated in the splicing pathway. Instead
column16: several of these factors have been previously implicated to play roles in chromatin remodeling
column17: 3' end processing
column18: and other novel categories. Further analysis of these factors using splicing-sensitive microarrays confirms that deletion of Bdf1
column19: a factor that links transcription initiation and chromatin remodeling
column20: leads to a global splicing defect
column21: providing evidence for a novel connection between pre-mRNA splicing and this component of the SWR1 complex. By contrast
column22: mutations in 3' end processing factors such as Cft2 and Yth1 also result in pre-mRNA splicing defects
column23: although only for a subset of transcripts
column24: suggesting that spliceosome assembly in S. cerevisiae may more closely resemble mammalian models of exon-definition. More broadly
column25: our work demonstrates the capacity of this approach to identify novel regulators of various cellular RNAs.

column1: OBJECTIVE: To differentiate severe/critical coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) infection from multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C).METHODS: Single-center chart review comparing characteristics of children with MIS-C and 'severe/critical' COVID-19 infection. Multivariate logistic regression was performed to create predictive models for predicting MIS-C.RESULTS: Of 68 patients
column2: 28 (41.2%) had MIS-C while 40 (58.8%) had severe/critical COVID-19 infection. MIS-C patients had a higher prevalence of fever
column3: mucocutaneous
column4: cardiac and gastrointestinal involvement and a lower prevalence of respiratory symptoms (P<0.05). Significantly lower hemoglobin
column5: platelet count
column6: serum electrolytes
column7: and significantly elevated inflammatory and coagulation markers were observed in MIS-C cohort. Upon multivariate logistic regression
column8: the best model included C-reactive protein (CRP)
column9: platelet count
column10: gastrointestinal and mucocutaneus involvement and absence of respiratory involvement (performance of 0.94). CRP>40 mg/L with either platelet count <150x109 or mucocutaneous involvement had specificity of 97.5% to diagnose MIS-C.CONCLUSION: Elevated CRP
column11: thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous involvement at presentation are helpful in differentiating MIS-C from severe COVID-19.

column1: Protein tyrosine kinases form a large family of signaling proteins implicated in both normal and malignant cell signaling. The aim of this study was to identify protein tyro-sine kinases that can transform hematopoietic cells to growth factor independent proliferation when constitutively activated by homodimerization. We used a modified retroviral insertion mutagenesis screen with a retroviral vector containing the homodimerization domain of ETV6 followed by an artificial splice donor site. Integration of this retroviral vector within a gene of the host genome would generate a fusion transcript containing the dimerization domain and part of the disrupted gene. Using this strategy with the IL3 dependent Ba/F3 cell line
column2: we identified 8 different protein tyrosine kinases (Abl1
column3: Fgfr1
column4: Hck
column5: Jak2
column6: Lck
column7: Mertk
column8: Mst1r
column9: Tnk1) that transformed the cells. These results characterize HCK
column10: MERTK
column11: MST1R and TNK1 as potential oncogenes and describe a method to identify gain-of-function fusion genes using a retroviral insertion screen.

column1: The nerve center responsible for controlling our circadian rhythm is located in a cluster of cells known as the suprachiasmatic nucleus in the hypothalamus. Various physiological functions such as sleep
column2: arousal
column3: blood pressure
column4: body temperature
column5: and hormone secretion are regulated in a 24-hour rhythm by this circuit. Somatic cells of other organs have a peripheral clock gene and by synchronizing the rhythm of the central and peripheral clocks
column6: it is possible to live a healthy life. Due to aging and degenerative disease
column7: circadian rhythm gradually collapses. Factors that can contribute to this include reduced expression of the time gene associated with photo stimulation
column8: a reduction in neurotransmitter levels
column9: and reduced melatonin production. Biological clocks play an important role in our emotions
column10: cognitive function
column11: and behavior. Sleep disorders and metabolic disease related to the circadian rhythm affect metabolic and endocrine activities via the autonomic nervous system and the intestinal bacterial flora. Shift work disorder is associated with insomnia and excessive drowsiness as individuals often work during their sleeping hours. Now time management is placed at the center of our society
column12: and it is important to evaluate the medical risk of engaging in shift work. In frontotemporal dementia (FTD)
column13: the stereotypical behaviors may be associated with time. In some patients
column14: multiple timed behaviors occupy a considerable part of the patient's daily life. Stereotypical behaviors in FTD are often considered in contrast to obsessive-compulsive disease (OCD). Studies of OCD have found a close correlation between clinical symptoms
column15: cognitive function
column16: and brain function.

column1: Overactive bladder (OAB)
column2: often accompanied by urinary incontinence
column3: is most prevalent among the elderly
column4: but also affects many middle-aged men and women in the US. OAB may severely impair quality of life
column5: and its overall economic costs to society are substantial. Although antimuscarinic agents relieve OAB symptoms effectively
column6: treatment persistence generally is low. This has been attributed in part to the occurrence of dry mouth and other anticholinergic adverse events. High plasma concentrations of N-desethyloxybutynin (DEO)
column7: an active metabolite of oxybutynin
column8: have been identified as the major cause of anticholinergic adverse effects associated with oral oxybutynin. Transdermal formulations of oxybutynin generate much lower DEO plasma concentrations compared with oral formulations. In a placebo-controlled US Phase III study in patients with OAB
column9: the recently approved oxybutynin topical gel (OTG) was efficacious and well tolerated. Dry mouth occurred in 6.9% of patients treated with OTG and 2.8% of patients on placebo. Incidences of other anticholinergic events were low and similar for OTG and placebo. OTG rarely caused application site skin reactions. OTG provides significant benefits to patients with OAB
column10: particularly those who are sensitive to anticholinergic adverse effects.

column1: Elagolix (ORILISSA™)
column2: an orally bioavailable
column3: second-generation
column4: non-peptide gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) receptor antagonist
column5: is being developed AbbVie and Neurocrine Biosciences for the treatment of reproductive hormone-dependent disorders in women. In July 2018
column6: the US FDA approved elagolix tablets for the management of moderate to severe pain associated with endometriosis. This approval was based on positive results in two replicate phase III trials; additional phase III trials in the USA
column7: Canada and Puerto Rico are currently evaluating elagolix as both monotherapy and in combination with low-dose hormone add-back therapy in the same indication. Elagolix with and without low-dose hormone add-back therapy is also undergoing phase III clinical development for heavy menstrual bleeding associated with uterine fibroids in the aforementioned locations. This article summarizes the milestones in the development of elagolix leading to its first approval for the management of moderate to severe pain associated with endometriosis.

column1: BACKGROUND: Current cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) methods
column2: such as late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) and oedema imaging (T2W) used to depict myocardial ischemia
column3: have limitations. Novel quantitative T1-mapping techniques have the potential to further characterize the components of ischemic injury. In patients with myocardial infarction (MI) we sought to investigate whether state-of the art pre-contrast T1-mapping (1) detects acute myocardial injury
column4: (2) allows for quantification of the severity of damage when compared to standard techniques such as LGE and T2W
column5: and (3) has the ability to predict long term functional recovery.METHODS: 3T CMR including T2W
column6: T1-mapping and LGE was performed in 41 patients [of these
column7: 78% were ST elevation MI (STEMI)] with acute MI at 12-48 hour after chest pain onset and at 6 months (6M). Patients with STEMI underwent primary PCI prior to CMR. Assessment of acute regional wall motion abnormalities
column8: acute segmental damaged fraction by T2W and LGE and mean segmental T1 values was performed on matching short axis slices. LGE and improvement in regional wall motion at 6M were also obtained.RESULTS: We found that the variability of T1 measurements was significantly lower compared to T2W and that
column9: while the diagnostic performance of acute T1-mapping for detecting myocardial injury was at least as good as that of T2W-CMR in STEMI patients
column10: it was superior to T2W imaging in NSTEMI. There was a significant relationship between the segmental damaged fraction assessed by either by LGE or T2W
column11: and mean segmental T1 values (P < 0.01). The index of salvaged myocardium derived by acute T1-mapping and 6M LGE was not different to the one derived from T2W (P = 0.88). Furthermore
column12: the likelihood of improvement of segmental function at 6M decreased progressively as acute T1 values increased (P < 0.0004).CONCLUSIONS: In acute MI
column13: pre-contrast T1-mapping allows assessment of the extent of myocardial damage. T1-mapping might become an important complementary technique to LGE and T2W for identification of reversible myocardial injury and prediction of functional recovery in acute MI.

column1: B cells play a central role in the pathogenesis in multiple sclerosis (MS)
column2: being involved in the activation of proinflammatory T cells
column3: secretion of proinflammatory cytokines
column4: and production of autoantibodies directed against myelin. Hence
column5: the usage of B-cell-depleting monoclonal antibodies as therapy for autoimmune diseases including MS lay near at hand. Rituximab was the first therapeutic B-cell-depleting chimeric monoclonal antibody to be used successfully in MS. Ocrelizumab
column6: a second-generation humanized anti-CD20 antibody
column7: was explored in a large phase II
column8: randomized
column9: placebo-controlled multicentre trial in patients with relapsing-remitting disease. Compared with placebo
column10: two doses of ocrelizumab (600 and 2000 mg on days 1 and 15) showed a pronounced effect on disease activity seen in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) as gadolinium-enhanced lesions (89% and 96% relative reduction
column11: both p < 0.001) and also had a significant effect on relapses. In exploratory analyses
column12: both doses of ocrelizumab had better effect on gadolinium-enhanced lesions than interferon beta-1a intramuscularly that was used as a reference arm. Adverse effects were mainly infusion-related reactions
column13: in particular during the first infusion. Serious infections occurred at similar rates in ocrelizumab and placebo-treated patients
column14: and no opportunistic infections were reported. However
column15: progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) has been reported in patients treated with anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies for other indications. Other anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies have been tested as treatments for MS
column16: including ofatumumab that has shown beneficial results in placebo-controlled phase II trials in patients with relapsing-remitting MS. Ocrelizumab is now in phase III development for the treatment of relapsing-remitting MS
column17: as well as primary progressive MS
column18: and the results of ongoing clinical trials are eagerly awaited and will determine the place of ocrelizumab in the armamentarium of MS therapies.

column1: Mammalian DNA replication initiates at multiple sites along chromosomes at different times during S phase
column2: following a temporal replication program. The specification of replication timing is thought to be a dynamic process regulated by tissue-specific and developmental cues that are responsive to epigenetic modifications. However
column3: the mechanisms regulating where and when DNA replication initiates along chromosomes remains poorly understood. Homologous chromosomes usually replicate synchronously
column4: however there are notable exceptions to this rule. For example
column5: in female mammalian cells one of the two X chromosomes becomes late replicating through a process known as X inactivation(1). Along with this delay in replication timing
column6: estimated to be 2-3 hr
column7: the majority of genes become transcriptionally silenced on one X chromosome. In addition
column8: a discrete cis-acting locus
column9: known as the X inactivation center
column10: regulates this X inactivation process
column11: including the induction of delayed replication timing on the entire inactive X chromosome. In addition
column12: certain chromosome rearrangements found in cancer cells and in cells exposed to ionizing radiation display a significant delay in replication timing of >3 hours that affects the entire chromosome(2
column13: 3). Recent work from our lab indicates that disruption of discrete cis-acting autosomal loci result in an extremely late replicating phenotype that affects the entire chromosome(4). Additional 'chromosome engineering' studies indicate that certain chromosome rearrangements affecting many different chromosomes result in this abnormal replication-timing phenotype
column14: suggesting that all mammalian chromosomes contain discrete cis-acting loci that control proper replication timing of individual chromosomes(5). Here
column15: we present a method for the quantitative analysis of chromosome replication timing combined with fluorescent in situ hybridization. This method allows for a direct comparison of replication timing between homologous chromosomes within the same cell
column16: and was adapted from(6). In addition
column17: this method allows for the unambiguous identification of chromosomal rearrangements that correlate with changes in replication timing that affect the entire chromosome. This method has advantages over recently developed high throughput micro-array or sequencing protocols that cannot distinguish between homologous alleles present on rearranged and un-rearranged chromosomes. In addition
column18: because the method described here evaluates single cells
column19: it can detect changes in chromosome replication timing on chromosomal rearrangements that are present in only a fraction of the cells in a population.

column1: The mechanisms by which the hereditary hemochromatosis protein
column2: HFE
column3: decreases transferrin-mediated iron uptake were examined. Coimmunoprecipitation studies using solubilized cell extracts demonstrated that transferrin (Tf) competed with HFE for binding to the transferrin receptor (TfR) similar to previous in vitro studies using soluble truncated forms of HFE and the TfR. At concentrations of Tf approaching those found in the blood
column4: no differences in Tf binding to cells were detected
column5: which is consistent with the lower binding constant of HFE for TfR versus Tf. However
column6: cells expressing HFE still showed a decrease in Tf-mediated iron uptake at concentrations of Tf sufficient to dissociate HFE from the TfR. These results indicate that the association of HFE with TfR is not essential for its ability to lower intracellular iron stores. To test the effect of HFE on lowering intracellular iron levels independently of its association with TfR
column7: a mutated HFE (fW81AHFE) that shows greatly reduced affinity for the TfR was transfected into tetracycline-controlled transactivator HeLa cells. HeLa cells expressing fW81AHFE behaved in a similar manner to cells expressing wild-type HFE with respect to decreased intracellular iron levels measured by iron regulatory protein gel-shift assays and ferritin levels. The results indicate that HFE can lower intracellular iron levels independently of its interaction with the TfR.

column1: As an approach to the rational design of combination chemotherapy involving the anti-cancer DNA topoisomerase II poison etoposide (VP-16)
column2: we have studied the dynamic changes occurring in small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) cell populations during protracted VP-16 exposure. Cytometric methods were used to analyse changes in target enzyme availability and cell cycle progression in a SCLC cell line
column3: mutant for the tumour-suppressor gene p53 and defective in the ability to arrest at the G1/S phase boundary. At concentrations up to 0.25 microM VP-16
column4: cells became arrested in G2 by 24 h exposure
column5: whereas at concentrations 0.25-2 microM G2 arrest was preceded by a dose-dependent early S-phase delay
column6: confirmed by bromodeoxyuridine incorporation. Recovery potential was determined by stathmokinetic analysis and was studied further in aphidicolin-synchronised cultures released from G1/S and subsequently exposed to VP-16 in early S-phase. Cells not experiencing a VP-16-induced S-phase delay entered G2 delay dependent upon the continued presence of VP-16. These cells could progress to mitosis during a 6-24 h period after drug removal. Cells experiencing an early S-phase delay remained in long-term G2 arrest with greatly reducing ability to enter mitosis up to 24 h after removal of VP-16. Irreversible G2 arrest was delimited by the induction of significant levels of DNA cleavage or fragmentation
column7: not associated with overt apoptosis
column8: in the majority of cells. Western blotting of whole-cell preparations showed increases in topoisomerase II levels (up to 4-fold) attributable to cell cycle redistribution
column9: while nuclei from cells recovering from S-phase delay showed enhanced immunoreactivity with an anti-topoisomerase II alpha antibody. The results imply that traverse of G1/S and early S-phase in the presence of a specific topoisomerase II poison gives rise to progressive low-level trapping of topoisomerase II alpha
column10: enhanced topoisomerase II alpha availability and the subsequent irreversible arrest in G2 of cells showing limited DNA fragmentation. We suggest that protracted
column11: low-dose chemotherapeutic regimens incorporating VP-16 are preferentially active towards cells attempting G1/S transition and have the potential for increasing the subsequent action of other topoisomerase II-targeted agents through target enzyme modulation. Combination modalities which prevent such dynamic changes occurring would act to reduce the effectiveness of the VP-16 component.

column1: Deciphering the molecular basis of cancer is critical for developing novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies. To better understand the early molecular events involving osteogenic sarcoma (OGS)
column2: we have initiated a program to identify potential tumor suppressor genes. Expression profiling of total RNA from ten normal bone cell lines and eleven OGS-derived cell lines by microarray showed 135-fold lower expression of FRZB/sFRP3 mRNA in OGS cells compared to bone cells; this down-regulation of Frzb/sFRP3 mRNA expression was found to be serum-independent. Subsequently
column3: fourteen OGS biopsy specimens showed nine-fold down-regulation of Frzb/sFRP3 mRNA expression compared to expression in eight normal bone specimens as determined by microarray. FRZB /sFRP3 protein level was also found to be at a very low level in 4/4 OGS cell lines examined. Quantitation by RT-PCR indicated approximately 70% and approximately 90% loss of Frzb/sFRP3 mRNA expression in OGS biopsy specimens and OGS-derived cell lines respectively
column4: compared to expression in bone (p<0.0001). Hybridization experiments of a cDNA microarray containing paired normal and tumor specimens from nineteen different organs did not show any significant difference in the level of Frzb/sFRP3 mRNA expression between the normal and the corresponding tumor tissues. Exogenous expression of FRZB/sFRP3 mRNA in two OGS-derived cell lines lacking endogenous expression of the mRNA produced abundant mRNA from the exogenous gene
column5: eliminating degradation as a possibility for very low level of FRZB/sFRP3 mRNA in OGS specimens. Results from PCR-based experiments suggest that the FRZB/sFRP3 gene is not deleted in OGS cell lines
column6: however
column7: karyotyping shows gross abnormalities involving chromosome 2 (location of the FRZB gene) in five of twelve OGS-derived cell lines. Together
column8: these data suggest a tumor-suppressive potential for FRZB/sFRP3 in OGS.

column1: Conjoined twins are rare phenomena occurring in one in 1 in 50
column2: 000 live births. Successful surgical separation of conjoined twins is a major undertaking requiring careful planning by a multidisciplinary team. Reports of seperation of joined twins in developing countries like Nigeria are rare. Ten cases of conjoined twins were separated between 1936 and January 2003 (including the authors two new cases). There were five omphalopagus
column3: two pygopagus
column4: two heterpagus and one ishiopagus twins. Three underwent emergency separation with 83.3% mortality while seven underwent elective seperation with 64.3% survival. The overall mortality rate was 50%. Despite the absence of advanced technological resource selected group of conjoined twins can be successfully separated in a developing country like Nigeria. An improvement in facilities and availability of trained personnel in likely to be associated with improved outcome.

column1: The Zika virus outbreak has captivated the attention of the global audience and information has spread rapidly and wildly through the internet and other media channels. This virus was first identified in 1947
column2: when it was isolated from a sentinel rhesus monkey placed by British scientists working at the Yellow Fever Research Laboratory located in the Zika forest area of Uganda
column3: hence its name
column4: and is transmitted primarily by the mosquito vector
column5: Aedes aegypti. The fact that the rhesus macaque is an Asian species being placed in an African forest brings to mind the possibility of rapid adaptation of the virus from an African to Asian species
column6: an issue that has not been considered. Whether such adaptation has played any role in acquiring pathogenicity due to cross species transmission remains to be identified. The first human infection was described in Nigeria in 1954
column7: with only scattered reports of about a dozen human infections identified over a 50-year period. It was not until 2007 that Zika virus raised its ugly head with infections noted in three-quarters of the population on the tiny island of Yap located between the Philippines and Papua New Guinea in the western Pacific Ocean
column8: followed by a major outbreak in French Polynesia in 2013. The virus remained confined to a narrow equatorial band in Africa and Asia until 2014 when it began to spread eastward
column9: first toward Oceania and then to South America. Since then
column10: millions of infected individuals have been identified in Brazil
column11: Colombia
column12: Venezuela
column13: including 25 additional countries in the Americas. While the symptoms associated with Zika virus infection are generally mild
column14: consisting of fever
column15: maculopapular rash
column16: arthralgia and conjunctivitis
column17: there have been reports of more severe reactions that are associated with neurological complications. In pregnant women
column18: fetal neurological complications include brain damage and microcephaly
column19: while in adults there have been several cases of virus-associated Guillain-Barre syndrome. The virus was until recently believed to only be transmitted via mosquitoes. But when the Zika virus was isolated from the semen specimens from a patient in Texas
column20: this provided the basis for the recent report of possible sexual transmission of the Zika virus. Due to the neurological complications
column21: various vectors for infection as well as the rapid spread throughout the globe
column22: it has prompted the World Health Organization to issue a global health emergency. Various governmental organizations have recommended that pregnant women do not travel to countries where the virus is epidemic
column23: and within the countries affected by the virus
column24: recommendations were provided for women of childbearing age to delay pregnancy. The overall public health impact of these above findings highlights the need for a rapid but specific diagnostic test for blood banks worldwide to identify those infected and for the counseling of women who are pregnant or contemplating pregnancy. As of this date
column25: there are neither commercially licensed diagnostic tests nor a vaccine. Because cross-reactivity of the Zika virus with dengue and Chikungunya virus is common
column26: it may pose difficulty in being able to quickly develop such tests and vaccines. So far the most effective public health measures include controlling the mosquito populations via insecticides and preventing humans from direct exposure to mosquitoes.

column1: Premature closure of cranial sutures (primary craniosynostosis) in children leads to characteristic skull deformities and prevents the constricted brain from growing normally. Although the cause remains unknown
column2: several etiological factors have been cited. Recently
column3: hypovascularity has been reported as a possible cause of craniosynostosis.METHODS: In a prospective study regional cerebral blood flow studies were carried out with 99mTc-HMPAO SPECT in seven children with craniosynostoses. Five preoperative and six postoperative studies were conducted and the results correlated with radiological and surgical findings.RESULTS: Preoperative studies revealed regional hypovascularity in the underlying cerebral hemisphere
column4: corresponding to the fused sutures. Postoperative studies revealed disappearance of these perfusion defects in most cases
column5: indicating normalization of perfusion following surgical decompression.CONCLUSION: This study establishes the presence of cerebral hypovascularity in craniosynostoses and suggests that early surgery and release of craniostenosis is essential to achieve optimum perfusion and brain development.

column1: DNA methylation of cytosine nucleotides is an important epigenetic modification that occurs in most eukaryotic organisms and is established and maintained by various DNA methyltransferases together with their co-factors. There are two major categories of DNA methyltransferases: de novo and maintenance. Here
column2: we report the isolation and functional characterization of a de novo methyltransferase
column3: named OsDRM2
column4: from rice (Oryza sativa L.). The full-length coding region of OsDRM2 was cloned and transformed into Escherichia coli and Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Both of these organisms expressed the OsDRM2 protein
column5: which exhibited stochastic de novo methylation activity in vitro at CG
column6: CHG
column7: and CHH di- and tri-nucleotide patterns. Two lines of evidence demonstrated the de novo activity of OsDRM2: (1) a 5'-CCGG-3' containing DNA fragment that had been pre-treated with OsDRM2 protein expressed in E. coli was protected from digestion by the CG-methylation-sensitive isoschizomer HpaII; (2) methylation-sensitive amplified polymorphism (MSAP) analysis of S. cerevisiae genomic DNA from transformants that had been introduced with OsDRM2 revealed CG and CHG methylation levels of 3.92-9.12%
column9: respectively
column10: whereas the mock control S. cerevisiae DNA did not exhibit cytosine methylation. These results were further supported by bisulfite sequencing of the 18S rRNA and EAF5 genes of the transformed S. cerevisiae
column11: which exhibited different DNA methylation patterns
column12: which were observed in the genomic DNA. Our findings establish that OsDRM2 is an active de novo DNA methyltransferase gene with conserved activity in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic non-host species.

column1: Apoptosis plays a crucial role in many biological processes and pathogenesis of various malignancies and diseases of the immune system. In this paper
column2: we described a novel method for sensitive detection of drug-induced apoptosis by using fluorescence correlation spectroscopy (FCS). The principle of this method is based on the assay of DNA fragmentation in the process of the drug-induced apoptosis. FCS is a single molecule method
column3: and it can be used for sensitive and selective assay of DNA fragmentation without separation. We first developed a highly sensitive method for characterization of DNA fragments using a home-built FCS system and SYBR Green I as fluorescent DNA-intercalating dye
column4: and then established a model of drug-induced apoptosis using human pancreatic cancer cells and a drug lidamycin. Furthermore
column5: FCS method established was used to directly detect the fragmentation of DNA extracted from apoptotic cells or in the apoptotic cell lysate. In FCS assay
column6: the single-component model and the multiple-components model were used to fit raw FCS data. The characteristic diffusion time of DNA fragments was used as an important parameter to distinguish the apoptotic status of cells. The obtained data documented that the characteristic diffusion time of DNA fragments from apoptotic cells significantly decreased with an increase of lidamycin concentration
column7: which implied that DNA fragmentation occurred in lidamycin-induced apoptosis. The FCS results are well in line with the data obtained from flow cytometer and gel electrophoresis. Compared to current methods
column8: the method described here is sensitive and simple
column9: and more importantly
column10: our detection volume is less than 1 fL
column11: and the sample requirement can easily be reduced to nL level using a droplets array technology. Therefore
column12: our method probably becomes a high throughput detection platform for early detection of cell apoptosis and screening of apoptosis-based anticancer drugs.

column1: INTRODUCTION: The biologic
column2: Ustekinumab (Stelara®
column3: Centocor
column4: Inc.
column5: Malvern
column6: PA
column7: USA)
column8: is a fully human monoclonal antibody with a high affinity for the shared p40 subunit of interleukins 12 and 23 (IL-12 and IL-23). Approved for use in treating moderate-to-severe psoriasis in 2009
column9: there has been considerable interest in the long-term safety of ustekinumab.AREAS COVERED: This review discusses the use of ustekinumab in the treatment of psoriasis and its potential to be an effective and well-tolerated therapy. A literature search was performed for articles published through April 2013 to identify any safety concerns.EXPERT OPINION: Our results indicate that ustekinumab has demonstrated higher efficacy rates as compared to traditional therapies; and with a favorable dosing schedule and stable safety profile
column10: patients with recalcitrant disease will now have another option for treatment.

column1: The new information presented in Digestive Disease Week has allowed us to speculate on the future of inflammatory bowel disease. Manipulation of diet and the microbioma will probably play an increasingly important role in the treatment of this disease and
column2: in the long term
column3: in its prevention. Biological agents will probably be used earlier and more widely; new information on levels of biological agents
column4: mucosal healing and new comparative studies will also allow these agents to be used in a more precise and personalized way. In addition to infliximab
column5: adalimumab
column6: natalizumab and certolizumab
column7: other biological agents will be employed; among the first of these to be used will be ustekinumab
column8: golimumab and vedolizumab. In the near future
column9: biological agents will be used as frequently in ulcerative colitis as in Crohn's disease. New healthcare models will be developed that will progressively include greater participation among patients and nurses. The ability to predict new diagnostic and prognostic models will allow decisions to be more individualized.

column1: To investigate the amount that radiation-induced secondary cancer would be reduced by using proton beam therapy (PBT) in place of intensity-modulated X-ray therapy (IMXT) in pediatric patients
column2: we analyzed lifetime attributable risk (LAR) as an in silico surrogate marker of the secondary cancer after these treatments. From 242 pediatric patients with cancers who were treated with PBT
column3: 26 patients were selected by random sampling after stratification into four categories: (i) brain
column4: head and neck
column5: (ii) thoracic
column6: (iii) abdominal
column7: and (iv) whole craniospinal (WCNS) irradiation. IMXT was replanned using the same computed tomography and region of interest. Using the dose-volume histograms (DVHs) of PBT and IMXT
column8: the LARs of Schneider et al. were calculated for the same patient. All the published dose-response models were tested for the organs at risk. Calculation of the LARs of PBT and IMXT based on the DVHs was feasible for all patients. The means ± standard deviations of the cumulative LAR difference between PBT and IMXT for the four categories were (i) 1.02 ± 0.52% (n = 7
column15: respectively (one tailed t-test). The numbers needed to treat (NNT) were (i) 98.0
column17: (iii) 6.0 and (iv) 2.0 for WCNS
column18: respectively. In pediatric patients who had undergone PBT
column19: the LAR of PBT was significantly lower than the LAR of IMXT estimated by in silico modeling. Although a validation study is required
column20: it is suggested that the LAR would be useful as an in silico surrogate marker of secondary cancer induced by different radiotherapy techniques.

column1: STUDY OBJECTIVE: To determine if a high score (≥ 3) on the STOP-Bang screening questionnaire for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) predicts whether obese patients are at high risk for OSA and increased risk of difficult airway.DESIGN: Prospective
column2: questionnaire-based clinical assessment.SETTING: University-affiliated hospital.PATIENTS: 127 ASA physical status 2 and 3 patients
column3: who were scheduled for elective bariatric surgery.INTERVENTIONS: Patients were allocated to three groups. Group 1 patients had a previous history of OSA
column4: Group 2 patients had no history of OSA but did have a high STOP-Bang score (≥ 3)
column5: and Group 3 patients had no history of OSA but did have a low STOP-Bang score (< 3). Groups 2 and 3 only were assessed using the STOP-Bang questionnaire. After induction and intubation of the patient
column6: an anesthesiologist who was blinded to the three study group allocations completed an airway questionnaire on the three study groups.MEASUREMENTS: The frequency of difficult airway
column7: difficult mask ventilation with or without muscle relaxation
column8: poor visualization of the vocal cords
column9: difficulty in blade insertion
column10: and difficult intubation were compared.MAIN RESULTS: The group of patients with high STOP-Bang scores (Group 2) and those patients previously diagnosed with OSA (Group1) showed a higher risk for difficult airway than the patients with low STOP-Bang scores (Group 3; P < 0.001).CONCLUSION: The STOP-Bang score may be used as an effective predictor of difficult airway in obese patients. Obese surgical patients with unknown/undiagnosed OSA status should be evaluated using the STOP-Bang questionnaire score.

column1: At least 27 alphaviruses and 68 flaviviruses have been recognized
column2: approximately one-third of which are medically important human pathogens. They vary widely in their basic ecology; each virus occupies a distinct ecologic niche
column3: often with restricted geographic and biologic distribution. As shown in Tables 54-1 and 54-2
column4: alphaviruses and flaviviruses can cause various syndromes
column5: ranging from benign febrile illnesses to severe systemic diseases with hemorrhagic manifestations or major organ involvement. The neurotropic alphaviruses and flaviviruses can produce severe destructive central nervous system disease with serious sequelae. Several alphaviruses (chikungunya
column6: Mayaro
column7: and Ross River) cause painful arthritis that persists for weeks or months after the initial febrile illness. Yellow fever virus has unique hepatotropic properties that cause a clinically and pathologically distinct form of hepatitis with a hemorrhagic diathesis. The dengue viruses
column8: which cause more human illness than all other members of their family
column9: may produce a serious
column10: sometimes fatal
column11: immunopathologic disease in which shock and hemorrhage occur. Hepatitis C virus (Chapter 70) may be a flavivirus. Alphavirus is one of the two genera in the family Togaviridae; the other genus (Rubivirus) has rubella virus (Chapter 55) as its only member. Flavivirus
column12: once classified in the Togaviridae
column13: now constitutes one of three genera in the family Flaviviridae; the other two genera are Pestivirus and “Hepatitis C-like viruses”. Pestivirus includes animal pathogens (bovine viral diarrhea and hog cholera viruses) that are of considerable economic importance
column14: but contains no known human pathogens. Hepatitis C virus is described in Chapter 70. All alphaviruses and flaviviruses that cause disease in humans are arthropod-borne viruses (arboviruses). In the original classification scheme based on antigenic relationships
column15: alphaviruses and flaviviruses were termed group A and group B arboviruses
column16: respectively. Most alphaviruses and flaviviruses survive in nature by replicating alternately in a vertebrate host and a hematophagous arthropod (mosquitoes or
column17: for some flaviviruses
column18: ticks). Arthropod vectors acquire the viral infection by biting a viremic host
column19: and after an extrinsic incubation period during which the virus replicates in the vector's tissues
column20: they transmit virus through salivary secretions to another vertebrate host. Virus replicates in the vertebrate host
column21: causing viremia and sometimes illness. The ability to infect and replicate in both vertebrate and arthropod cells is an essential quality of alphaviruses and flaviviruses. The principal vertebrate hosts for most are various species of wild mammals or birds. The natural zoonotic cycles that maintain the virus do not usually involve humans. However
column22: a few viruses (yellow fever virus
column25: 3 and 4 and chikungunya virus) can be transmitted in a human-mosquito-human cycle. As a result of being pathogenic for humans and capable of transmission in heavily populated areas
column26: these viruses can cause widespread and serious epidemics. Because of their high transmission potential
column27: these viruses are major public health problems in many tropical and subtropical regions of the world where appropriate mosquito vectors are present. Because some of these agents are dangerous human pathogens and are highly infectious
column28: special containment and safety precautions in the laboratory are required.

column1: Aromatic L-amino acid decarboxylase (AADC) deficiency is a rare pediatric neuro-metabolic disease in children. Due to the lack of an animal model
column2: its pathogenetic mechanism is poorly understood. To study the role of AADC in brain development
column3: a zebrafish model of AADC deficiency was generated. We identified an aadc gene homolog
column4: dopa decarboxylase (ddc)
column5: in the zebrafish genome. Whole-mount in situ hybridization analysis showed that the ddc gene is expressed in the epiphysis
column6: locus caeruleus
column7: diencephalic catecholaminergic clusters
column8: and raphe nuclei of 36-h post-fertilization (hpf) zebrafish embryos. Inhibition of Ddc by AADC inhibitor NSD-1015 or anti-sense morpholino oligonucleotides (MO) reduced brain volume and body length. We observed increased brain cell apoptosis and loss of dipencephalic catecholaminergic cluster neurons in ddc morphants (ddc MO-injected embryos). Seizure-like activity was also detected in ddc morphants in a dose-dependent manner. ddc morphants had less sensitive touch response and impaired swimming activity that could be rescued by injection of ddc plasmids. In addition
column9: eye movement was also significantly impaired in ddc morphants. Collectively
column10: loss of Ddc appears to result in similar phenotypes as that of ADCC deficiency
column11: thus zebrafish could be a good model for investigating pathogenetic mechanisms of AADC deficiency in children.

column1: Cytosolic proteins can be selectively delivered to lysosomes for degradation through a type of autophagy known as chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA). CMA contributes to intracellular quality control and to the cellular response to stress. Compromised CMA has been described in aging and in different age-related disorders. CMA substrates cross the lysosomal membrane through a translocation complex; consequently
column2: changes in the properties of the lysosomal membrane should have a marked impact on CMA activity. In this work
column3: we have analyzed the impact that dietary intake of lipids has on CMA activity. We have found that chronic exposure to a high-fat diet or acute exposure to a cholesterol-enriched diet both have an inhibitory effect on CMA. Lysosomes from livers of lipid-challenged mice had a marked decrease in the levels of the CMA receptor
column4: the lysosome-associated membrane protein type 2A
column5: because of loss of its stability at the lysosomal membrane. This accelerated degradation of lysosome-associated membrane protein type 2A
column6: also described as the mechanism that determines the decline in CMA activity with age
column7: results from its increased mobilization to specific lipid regions at the lysosomal membrane. Comparative lipidomic analyses revealed qualitative and quantitative changes in the lipid composition of the lysosomal membrane of the lipid-challenged animals that resemble those observed with age. Our findings identify a previously unknown negative impact of high dietary lipid intake on CMA and underscore the importance of diet composition on CMA malfunction in aging.

column1: The development of antibody-drug conjugates composed of a cytotoxic agent and a monoclonal antibody carrier offers an important alternative to classic chemotherapy strategies. Trastuzumab deruxtecan (DS-8201a) is a next-generation antibody-drug conjugate composed of a monoclonal anti-HER2 antibody and a topoisomerase I inhibitor
column2: an exatecan derivative (DX-8951f). DS-8201a resulted in favorable outcomes in HER2-positive heavily pretreated breast cancer patients and also had a promising efficacy in patients with HER2-negative/low-expressing disease
column3: whose options are limited. Interestingly
column4: a recently published phase 2 trial (NCT03248492) reported 60% overall response and 97% disease control in patients with HER2-positive disease previously treated with multiple regimens
column5: including trastuzumab emtansine. On the basis of recent clinical trials
column6: the US Food and Drug Administration granted accelerated approval to DS-8201a in advanced or unresectable HER2-positive breast cancer pretreated with at least two HER2-targeting treatment lines. We review all preclinical and clinical data of DS-8201a regarding breast cancer.

column1: Thyroid hormone has many effects on the heart and cardiovascular system. Thyrotoxicosis is associated with increased cardiovascular morbidity and mortality
column2: primarily due to heart failure and thromboembolism. However
column3: the relationship between thyroid hormone excess and the cardiac complications of angina pectoris and myocardial infarction remains largely speculative. Moreover
column4: few studies have been reported on the effect of thyroid hormone levels within normal range on coronary artery disease (CAD). Therefore we examined the association of thyroid function with coronary artery diseases in euthyroid angina patients. Total 192 subjects (mean age; 60.8 yrs) were enrolled in which coronary angiograms were performed due to chest pain. We measured free thyroxine (FT(4))
column5: thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)
column6: serum lipid levels and high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hsCRP) levels and analyzed their association with the presence of CAD. Serum FT(4) levels were higher in patients with CAD compared with the patients without CAD (1.31 +/- 0.30 vs 1.20 +/- 0.23
column8: and high FT(4) level was associated with the presence of multi-vessel disease. Multivariate analysis showed that age (odds ratio (OR) 1.04; 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.01-1.07
column10: hypertension (OR 2.04; 95% CI 1.06-3.90
column13: were the determinants for CAD. The relative risk (RR) for CAD in highest tertile of FT(4) showed increased risk compared with the lowest tertile (RR 1.98; 95% CI 0.98-3.99
column14: p<0.001). Our study showed that FT(4) levels were associated with the presence and the severity of CAD. Also
column15: this study suggests that elevated serum FT(4) levels even within normal range could be a risk factor for CAD. Further studies will be necessary to confirm the relationship of thyroid function and CAD.

column1: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) remains a challenging medical problem. The integral approach to the analysis of underlying pathogenetic processes allows identifying main symptom complexes of SLE and establishing relationship between skin lesions and activity of the disease. We examined 84 patients with SLE (84% women)
column2: their mean age was 42.3 +/- 2.3 yr duration of SLE 6.5 +/- 1.2 yr. The subacute and chronic SLE variants were diagnosed in 30 (36%) and 54 (64%) patients respectively. Grade 1 and 2-3 inflammatory process occurred in 53 (63%) and 31 (37%) patients respectively. Symptom complexes "systemic inflammation"
column3: "butterfly rash"
column4: "wrist petechiae"
column5: "enanthema of the oral mucous membrane"
column6: and other lesions were regarded as the markers of SLE activity. The relationship of lupus-cheilitis and facial erythema with polyserositis and pericarditis ("visceral pathology-cardiovascular lesions") requires instrumental examination of pericardium
column7: pleural and abdominal cavities in the patients with the above skin symptoms for diagnostics of polyserositis. At the same time
column8: the presence of teleangiectasia on the wrists (symptom complex "visceral pathology-renoparenchymatous lesions") requires thorough examination of the renal function. The presence of erythema at the major joints
column9: mesh livedo
column10: and Raynaud's syndrome (symptom complex "musculoskeletal disorders") implies specialized examination of the locomotor apparatus.

column1: Epoxyeicosatrienoic acids (EETs) are arachidonic acid metabolites produced by cytochrome P450 epoxygenases which are highly expressed in hepatocytes. The functions of EETs in hepatocytes are not well understood. In this study
column2: we investigated the effects of 14
column3: 15-EETs treatment on the insulin signal transduction pathway in hepatocytes. We report that chronic treatment
column4: not acute treatment
column5: with 30 μM 14
column6: 15-EETs prevents palmitate induced insulin resistance and potentiates insulin action in cultured HepG2 hepatocytes. 14
column7: 15-EETs increase Akt phosphorylation at S473
column8: activating Akt
column9: in an insulin dependent manner in HepG2 cells. Under insulin resistant conditions induced by palmitate
column11: 15-EETs restore the insulin response by increasing S473-phosphorylated Akt. 8
column12: 9-EETs and 11
column13: 12-EETs demonstrated similar effects to 14
column14: 15-EETs. Furthermore
column16: 15-EETs potentiate insulin-suppression of gluconeogenesis in cultured H4IIE hepatocytes. To elucidate the mechanism of EETs function
column17: we analyzed the insulin signaling factors upstream of Akt. Inhibition of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) with LY294002 attenuated the 14
column18: 15-EETs-induced activating phosphorylation of Akt. 14
column19: 15-EETs reduced palmitate-stimulated phosphorylation of IRS-1 on S312 and phosphorylation of c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) at threonine 183 and tyrosine 185 residues. The regulation of insulin sensitivity in cultured hepatocytes by chronic 14
column20: 15-EETs treatment appears to involve the JNK-IRS-PI3K pathway. The requirement of chronic treatment with EETs suggests that the effects of EETs on insulin response may be indirect.

column1: A host cytidine deaminase
column2: APOBEC3G (A3G)
column3: inhibits replication of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) by incorporating into virions in the absence of the virally encoded Vif protein (Deltavif virions)
column4: at least in part by causing G-to-A hypermutation. To gain insight into the antiretroviral function of A3G
column5: we determined the quantities of A3G molecules that are incorporated in Deltavif virions. We combined three experimental approaches-reversed-phase high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC)
column6: scintillation proximity assay (SPA)
column7: and quantitative immunoblotting-to determine the molar ratio of A3G to HIV-1 capsid protein in Deltavif virions. Our studies revealed that the amount of the A3G incorporated into Deltavif virions was proportional to the level of its expression in the viral producing cells
column8: and the ratio of the A3G to Gag in the Deltavif virions produced from activated human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) was approximately 1:439. Based on previous estimates of the stoichiometry of HIV-1 Gag in virions (1400-5000)
column9: we conclude that approximately 7 (+/-4) molecules of A3G are incorporated into Deltavif virions produced from human PBMCs. These results indicate that virion incorporation of only a few molecules of A3G is sufficient to inhibit HIV-1 replication.

column1: AIM: ATP-sensitive potassium channels are important regulators of insulin secretion. They consist of four sulphonylurea receptor (encoded by ABCC8) and four inwardly rectifying protein (encoded by KCNJ11) subunits. Activating ABCC8 mutations lead to decreased insulin secretion and to diabetes. Wide phenotype variability is associated with single ABCC8 mutations
column2: ranging from transient or permanent neonatal diabetes (ND) with or without developmental delay (DEND syndrome) to very mild phenotypes. This report describes the case of a Caucasian infant diagnosed with ND at the age of 2 months due to a novel ABCC8 missense mutation.METHODS: ABCC8 was analyzed by sequence analysis. The mutation was present in the patient and her family and was found to be associated with phenotypes ranging from ND to asymptomatic impaired fasting glucose (IFG).RESULTS: A novel His863Tyr ABCC8 mutation was identified in a 2-month-old girl diagnosed with ND. After an initial insulin treatment
column3: treatment with glibenclamide was initiated and the treatment with insulin discontinued. The same mutation was found in her father
column4: who had been fortuitously diagnosed with diabetes and had an HbA(1c) level of 9% (74.8 mmol/mol). The patient's brother and mother both had normal fasting glucose
column5: and were not found to be carriers of the mutation. However
column6: the same mutation was found in her grandmother
column7: who had been asymptomatic and discovered IFG (6.9 mmol/L) with an HbA(1c) of 6.8% (50.8 mmol/mol).CONCLUSION: This case describes a novel ABCC8 mutation and offers a further illustration of the highly variable phenotypes associated with an identical mutation present across three generations.

column1: Toll-like receptor (TLR)4 regulates inflammation and metabolism and has been linked to the pathogenesis of heart disease. TLR4 is upregulated in diabetic cardiomyocytes
column2: and we examined the role of TLR4 in modulating cardiac fatty acid (FA) metabolism and the pathogenesis of diabetic heart disease in nonobese diabetic (NOD) mice. Both wild-type (WT) NOD and TLR4-deficient NOD animals had increased plasma triglyceride levels after the onset of diabetes. However
column3: by comparison
column4: TLR4-deficient NOD mouse hearts had lower triglyceride accumulation in the early stages of diabetes
column5: which was associated with a reduction in myeloid differentiation primary response gene (88) (MyD88)
column6: phosphorylation of p38 MAPK (phospho-p38)
column7: lipoprotein lipase (LPL)
column8: and JNK levels but increased phospho-AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK). Oleic acid treatment in H9C2 cardiomyocytes also led to cellular lipid accumulation
column9: which was attenuated by TLR4 small interfering RNA. TLR4 deficiency in the cells decreased FA-induced augmentation of MyD88
column10: phospho-p38
column11: and LPL
column12: suggesting that TLR4 may modulate FA-induced lipid metabolism in cardiomyocytes. In addition
column13: although cardiac function was impaired in both diabetic WT NOD and TLR4-deficient NOD animals compared with control nondiabetic mice
column14: this deficit was less in the diabetic TLR4-deficient NOD mice
column15: which had greater ejection fraction
column16: greater fractional shortening
column17: and increased left ventricular developed pressure in the early stages after the development of diabetes compared with their diabetic WT NOD counterparts. Thus
column18: we conclude that TLR4 plays a role in regulating lipid accumulation in cardiac muscle after the onset of type 1 diabetes
column19: which may contribute to cardiac dysfunction.

column1: We present a unique case of crowned dens syndrome (CDS) that developed after endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) in a patient who presented with fever and neck pain. Administration of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs was extremely effective for relieving fever and neck pain
column2: and in the improvement of inflammatory markers. To the best of our knowledge
column3: this is the first case report of CDS caused by an ERCP procedure. In a patient with fever and neck pain after an ERCP procedure
column4: CDS should be considered in the differential diagnosis.

column1: Aortitis is defined as an inflammatory process that involves one or more layers of the aortic wall (internal elastic lamina
column2: tunica media
column3: and adventitia) and can be caused by multiple mechanisms. Clinical features are usually nonspecific and a high index of suspicion is required for making the diagnosis. Although noninvasive imaging studies are being increasingly used in evaluating patients for diagnosis
column4: angiography remains the gold standard for confirming aortic involvement. When tissue is available
column5: pathologic examination can aid in clarifying the diagnosis. Aortitis
column6: irrespective of the underlying cause
column7: frequently displays similar clinical
column8: pathologic
column9: and arteriographic features and therefore understandably presents a therapeutic and diagnostic dilemma. Whatever the cause
column10: early identification and aggressive treatment is required in order to avert the potentially life-threatening sequelae. The treatment of aortitis is determined by the underlying cause. If diagnosed early
column11: infectious aortitis responds to appropriate antimicrobial therapy
column12: whereas noninfectious
column13: immune-mediated aortitis requires immunosuppressive therapy. However
column14: in many instances
column15: primarily because of the delay in diagnosis
column16: surgical intervention is necessary to treat the associated anatomic and physiologic sequelae. Less definitive and more controversial is the role of inflammation in both primary and secondary accelerated atherosclerosis of the aorta and its modality of treatment.

column1: Drug transporters are an important part of the defense of cells against cytotoxic agents. One major group of transporters is known as multidrug resistance associated proteins (MRP; ABCC gene family). The MRPs belong to the ATP binding cassette transporter superfamily. One family member
column2: ABCC4 (also known as MRP4) functions as a cellular efflux pump for anti-HIV drugs
column3: such as 9-(2-phoshoenylmethoxyethyl) adenine and azido-thymidine-monophosphate
column4: an antiviral nucleotide
column5: ganciclovir-monophosphate
column6: and anti-cancer agents such as thiopurines. We isolated a ABCC4 cDNA encoding a non-functional protein
column7: owing to an insertion
column8: and subsequently determined the ABCC4 gene structure. This analysis revealed that the insertion was attributed to two additional exons that would be predicted to produce premature termination codons (PTC) in ABCC4. The highly similar mouse Abcc4 gene also contained these exons
column9: which were remarkable because their size and sequence identity were much higher than the overall similarity between these genes. Further
column10: a comparison of human
column11: monkey and rodent ABCC4 genes revealed that these same PTC-producing exons were also highly conserved in evolution. As all the ABCC4 mRNA containing these PTC exons might produce nonsense mRNA
column12: we further tested the hypothesis that these mRNAs were targets of nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (NMD). Protein synthesis inhibition selectively stabilized PTC containing ABCC4 transcripts in human
column13: monkey and rodent cell lines. Moreover
column14: the amount of PTC-containing ABCC4 transcripts was critically dependent upon protein synthesis
column15: as removal of the inhibitor dramatically decreased expression
column16: which correlated with the resumption of protein synthesis. These are the first studies to indicate that the highly conserved PTC exons of the ABCC4 gene may dictate its expression.

column1: Gaucher's disease (GD) results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme glucocerebrosidase and
column2: in very rare occasions
column3: a deficiency of its activator
column4: the saposin C. The complexity of identification and characterization of mutations in the gene of glucocerebrosidase (GBA1) is caused by a great amount of mutated alleles
column5: the existence of a highly homologous pseudogene and its location in a very rich zone in genes
column6: which promotes the presence of complex alleles. Although genotype-phenotype correlations in EG are not completely established
column7: there are a series of generalities
column8: as the mutation c.1226A>G (N370S) is often associated with a certain degree of neuroprotection and the homozygosity for the c.1448T>C (L444P) mutation presents with neurological symptoms.

column1: The interplay between tumor cells and their microenvironment plays a pivotal role in tumor development and progression. Although a growing body of evidence has established the importance of the tumor microenvironment
column2: an understanding of the crosstalk between its components and cancer cells remains elusive. The pathways triggered by microenvironmental factors could modulate cancer-related gene transcription
column3: also affecting small noncoding RNAs
column4: microRNAs
column5: which have emerged as key posttranscriptional regulators of gene expression
column6: directly involved in human cancers. Although microRNAs regulate most biological mechanisms
column7: their role in the tumor microenvironment has only recently become the focus of intense research. In this paper
column8: we focus on the intertwined connection between the tumor microenvironment and aberrant expression of microRNAs involved in carcinogenesis. We also discuss the emerging roles of microRNAs in the tumor microenvironment as it relates to cancer progression. We conclude that microRNAs are critical for our understanding of the development of cancer
column9: and that targeting microRNA signaling pathways in the microenvironment as well as in tumor cells opens new therapeutic avenues to the global control of cancer.

column1: The continuous itaconic acid production from sucrose with Aspergillus terreus TKK 200-5-3 mycelium immobilized on polyurethane foam cubes was optimized in column bioreactors using statistical experimental design and empirical modelling. The highest itaconic acid product concentration calculated on the basis of the obtained model was 15.8 g l-1 in the investigated experimental area
column2: when sucrose concentration was 13.5%
column3: aeration rate 150 ml min-1 and residence time 178 h. From sucrose with immobilized A. terreus TKK 200-5-3 mycelium itaconic acid production was stable for at least 4.5 months in continuous column bioreactors. In comparison
column4: using glucose as substrate and immobilized A. terreus TKK 200-5-1 mycelium as biocatalyst similar stability was obtained with higher product concentration. The omission of copper sulphate from the production medium gave the highest itaconic acid product concentration (26 g l-1) from 9% glucose with 0.25% ammonium nitrate and 0.095% magnesium sulphate.

column1: BACKGROUND: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death
column2: and principal reason for the large difference in life expectancy between indigenous Māori and the non-indigenous population in New Zealand. CVD guidelines recommend that people who are at high risk or who have had previous CVD should be offered aspirin
column3: blood pressure lowering and lipid lowering therapies. However
column4: prescribing and adherence rates are low and CVD events remain high.AIM: To assess whether a medication strategy using a fixed dose combination pill ('polypill') could improve prescribing and adherence to recommended medications
column5: lower blood pressure and improve lipids compared with current care over 12 months.METHODS: IMProving Adherence using Combination Therapy (IMPACT) is an open-label randomised controlled trial comparing a once-daily polypill containing four preventive medications with usual care. Six hundred participants who have had previous CVD events or are at high risk of CVD will be enrolled
column6: including 300 Māori. Participants are identified
column7: enrolled and prescribed either the polypill or current medications at their usual primary health care practice
column8: with medications (including the polypill) dispensed through local community pharmacies. The polypill contains 75 mg aspirin
column9: 40 mg simvastatin
column10: 10mg lisinopril and either 12.5mg hydrochlorothiazide or 50mg atenolol. Primary outcomes are adherence to guidelines-recommended medications and changes in systolic blood pressure and low density lipoprotein at 12 months. Secondary outcomes include other lipids
column11: medication dispensing
column12: barriers to adherence
column13: CVD and other serious adverse events
column14: quality of life and prescriber acceptability. The trial is registered with the Australian New Zealand Clinical Trial Registry (ACTRN12606000067572).

column1: Naturally occurring foam constituent and surfactant proteins with intriguing structures and functions are now being identified from a variety of biological sources. The ranaspumins from tropical frog foam nests comprise a range of proteins with a mixture of surfactant
column2: carbohydrate binding and antimicrobial activities that together provide a stable
column3: biocompatible
column4: protective foam environment for developing eggs and embryos. Ranasmurfin
column5: a blue protein from a different species of frog
column6: displays a novel structure with a unique chromophoric crosslink. Latherin
column7: primarily from horse sweat
column8: but with similarities to salivary
column9: oral and upper respiratory tract proteins
column10: illustrates several potential roles for surfactant proteins in mammalian systems. These proteins
column11: together with the previously discovered hydrophobins of fungi
column12: throw new light on biomolecular processes at air-water and other interfaces. This review provides a perspective on these recent findings
column13: focussing on structure and biophysical properties.

column1: The concept of thyroid hormone (TH) analogs that retain the beneficial effects of TH excess on lipid lowering and fat metabolism
column2: while avoiding any harmful effects on the heart
column3: muscle
column4: bone and other tissues
column5: has interested scientists and physicians for several decades. While there have been many attempts to develop selective TH receptor (TR) modulators (STRMs) for safe lipid lowering
column6: these approaches have failed consistently. This review details recent advances in the development of TRβ subtype- and liver-selective STRM analogs
column7: and presents the results of preliminary clinical trials with one of these compounds
column8: eprotirome (KB-2115; Karo Bio AB).

column1: Haploinsufficiency of the NSD1 gene due to 5q35 microdeletions or intragenic mutations is the major cause of Sotos syndrome characterized by generalized overgrowth
column2: large hands and feet with advanced bone age
column3: craniofacial dysmorphic features
column4: learning disability
column5: and possible susceptibility to tumors. Here
column6: we report on a 14-month-old boy with a reverse phenotype of Sotos syndrome due to the reciprocal duplication of the 5q35.3 region
column7: including the NSD1 gene
column8: detected by array CGH. The phenotype includes delayed bone age
column9: microcephaly
column10: seizures
column11: and failure to thrive. Our case suggests that the gene dosage effect of the NSD1 gene is the likely cause for the reversed phenotype of Sotos syndrome in this patient.

column1: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a rare
column2: acquired disorder characterized by chronic intravascular hemolysis as the primary clinical manifestation and morbidities that include anemia
column3: thrombosis
column4: renal impairment
column5: pulmonary hypertension
column6: and bone marrow failure. The prevalence of the PNH clone (from <1-100% PNH granulocytes) is approximately 16 per million
column7: and careful monitoring is required. The average age of onset of the clinical disease is the early 30s
column8: although it can present at all ages. PNH is caused by the acquisition of a somatic mutation of the gene phosphatidylinositol glycan anchor (PIG-A) in a multipotent hematopoietic stem cell (HSC)
column9: with clonal expansion of the mutated HSC. The mutation causes a deficiency in the synthesis of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI). In cells derived from normal HSCs
column10: the complement regulatory proteins CD55 and CD59 are anchored to the hematopoietic cell membrane surface via GPI
column11: protecting the cells from complement-mediated lysis. However
column12: in patients with PNH
column13: these 2 proteins
column14: along with numerous other GPI-linked proteins
column15: are absent from the cell surface of red cells
column16: granulocytes
column17: monocytes
column18: and platelets
column19: resulting in complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis and other complications. Lysis of red blood cells is the most obvious manifestation
column20: but as other cell lineages are also affected
column21: this complement-mediated attack contributes to additional complications
column22: such as thrombosis. Eculizumab
column23: a humanized monoclonal antibody against the C5 complement protein
column24: is the only effective drug therapy for PNH patients. The antibody prevents cleavage of the C5 protein by C5 convertase
column25: in turn preventing generation of C5b-9 and release of C5a
column26: thereby protecting from hemolysis of cells lacking the CD59 surface protein and other complications associated with complement activation. Drs. Ilene C. Weitz
column27: Anita Hill
column28: and Jeff Szer discuss 3 recent cases of patients with PNH.

column1: INTRODUCTION: Cerebrolysin is a neuroprotective drug used in the treatment of acute ischemic stroke. To our knowledge
column2: this drug has never been evaluated in patients with aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of Cerebrolysin in patients with aneurysmal SAH.METHODS: Aneurysmal SAH patients who had their aneurysm obliterated at our institution from 2007 to 2016 were retrospectively studied. Patients received Cerebrolysin treatment or standard care only (control group). Subgroup analyses were performed according to Hunt and Hess grade (good grade ≤ 2
column3: N = 216; poor grade ≥ 3
column4: N = 246) and treatment procedure (clip or coil).RESULTS: In good-grade patients (N = 216)
column5: clinical outcomes and mortality did not differ significantly between the control and Cerebrolysin groups. In poor-grade patients (N = 246)
column6: the mortality rate was significantly lower in the Cerebrolysin group (8.7%) than in the control group (25.4%
column7: p = 0.006). In patients who received microsurgical clipping (N = 328)
column8: the mortality rate was significantly lower in the Cerebrolysin group (7.3%) than in the control group (18.5%
column9: p = 0.016).CONCLUSION: Cerebrolysin injection during the acute period of SAH appeared to reduce the mortality rate
column10: especially in poor-grade patients. This study suggests the potential of Cerebrolysin for treating aneurysmal SAH. Further studies are needed to confirm our results.

column1: A patient is described with idiopathic Parkinson's disease and severe laryngeal stridor. Other than urinary frequency and urgency
column2: not uncommon in this condition
column3: and postoperative levodopa-sensitive postural hypotension
column4: there were no features of generalized autonomic failure. The laryngeal stridor responded to levodopa therapy
column5: and we are not aware that this has been reported previously.

column1: The transcription factor E2F1 has a key function during S phase progression and apoptosis. It has been well-demonstrated that the apoptotic function of E2F1 involves its ability to transactivate pro-apoptotic target genes. Alternative splicing of pre-mRNAs also has an important function in the regulation of apoptosis. In this study
column2: we identify the splicing factor SC35
column3: a member of the Ser-Rich Arg (SR) proteins family
column4: as a new transcriptional target of E2F1. We demonstrate that E2F1 requires SC35 to switch the alternative splicing profile of various apoptotic genes such as c-flip
column5: caspases-8 and -9 and Bcl-x
column6: towards the expression of pro-apoptotic splice variants. Finally
column7: we provide evidence that E2F1 upregulates SC35 in response to DNA-damaging agents and show that SC35 is required for apoptosis in response to these drugs. Taken together
column8: these results demonstrate that E2F1 controls pre-mRNA processing events to induce apoptosis and identify the SC35 SR protein as a key direct E2F1-target in this setting.

column1: Herpes zoster (HZ; shingles) results from reactivation of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) after primary infection as varicella (chicken pox). It affects mainly older adults and people with immunocompromising diseases or treatments. The most common complication is postherpetic neuralgia (PHN)
column2: which has significant adverse effects on quality of life and activities of daily living. Since PHN cannot be prevented once HZ has occurred
column3: and treatment is only modestly successful and is associated with significant side effects
column4: the recent introduction of an effective vaccine is an important achievement. This new vaccine
column5: which combines a single VZV glycoprotein (gE) and a multicomponent adjuvant
column6: is superior to the previously available live attenuated VZV vaccine. The recombinant adjuvanted vaccine is remarkably effective in restoring the protective T cell-mediated immunity required to prevent HZ. Its clinical efficacy is much greater than that observed with other vaccines for older individuals affected by immune senescence
column7: and its safety profile is very acceptable. It has been recommended in the USA and Canada for people who are 50 years of age and older. The immunogenicity and safety of this vaccine in severely immunocompromised individuals
column8: such as after chemotherapy for malignancy
column9: after solid organ or stem cell transplant
column10: and in people with HIV are being studied.

column1: Although mass spectrometry has become a powerful tool for the functional analysis of biological systems
column2: complete proteome characterization cannot yet be achieved. Instead
column3: the sheer complexity of living organisms demands fractionation of cellular extracts to enable more targeted analyses. Here
column4: we introduce the concept of "fluorous proteomics
column5:
whereby specific peptide subsets from samples of biological origin are tagged with perfluorinated moieties and subsequently enriched by solid-phase extraction over a fluorous-functionalized stationary phase. This approach is extremely selective, yet can readily be tailored to enrich different subsets of peptides. Additionally, this methodology overcomes many of the limitations of traditional bioaffinity-based enrichment strategies, while enabling new affinity enrichment schemes impossible to implement with bioaffinity reagents.
